FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
JAMES CARROLL
div1.p:
James Carroll, the second in command on the United States
Army Yellow Fever Commission, was an Englishman, born at Woolwich, on June
5, 1854. His early years, like those of allmany men whose maturity is spent
in a country not theirs own by birth, are little known, especially as his own
entire lack of egotism prevented his dwelling upon them. He was educated a- Albion House with a
view to entering the British Army as an engineer student, but shortly be-
? fore the time came for him to do so, he emigrated to Canada, in consequence,
as he once told me, of us disappointment in an youthful love affair. For
some time after he reached Canada, his life was that of a farmer in the back-
woods, butuntil in 1874 he is the in course of time he came to the United States
and in January 1874 entered the United States Army.

AfterUpon enlisting he was ordered to the Far West and while serving
there in Montana, as a hospital steward, he became interested in the study
of medicine. After some difficulty- he obtained permission to attend medical lec-
lec tures a became at St. Paul, Minnesota, and from this time on he pursued his
medical education as he could and where he could, until, on his return to the
East, he finally completed it at the University of the City of New York and
the University of Maryland, receiving his degree asof M. D. from the latter in-

of bacteriology, which was then just beginning to develop in this country, and availed him-
self of the graduate classes just opened at the Johns Hopkins Hospital to
take upprosecute this line of work. In 1895 he was assigned to duty in the Army
Medical Museum at Washington, where Walter Reed was Curator, and from this
time on their names of these two eminent colaborers were constantly associated. In 1899 they Reed & Carroll were both appoint-
ed by Surgeon-General Sternberg to investigate into the true nature of the
bacillus icteroides which Sanarelli had just declared to bewas the specific
agent in yellow fever. Their work on this subject naturally associated
their names prominently with the great yellow fever question &, so it came about that and in 1900, when an Army Medical Commission
was appointed to go to Cuba and investigate into the nature and transmission of this disease scourge of the centuries
in Cuba. Reed was made Chairman with Carroll asplaced second in command.

Carroll arrived in Cuba on June 25, 1900, and shortly afterwards
the preliminary experiments were begun. Early in the course of the work
it became apparent to the members of the Commission that the proposed line
of work could not be carried on without experiments upon human beings and
they agreed that the initial experiment must be made upon one of themselves.
Carroll volunteered for this service, and he always said that the proudest
circumstances of his life was that he was the first person to succumb to

ring which his life was despaired of, and although he recovered, as it seemed
completely, he did soit was with an organic heart lesion which ultimately caused
his death.

Carroll's services upon the Yellow Fever Commission, apart from
the inestimable one act of self sacrifice just mentioned, were of the most essential kindcharacter, and
it is not at all too much to say that without his native force of character and
perseverance, in addition toguided by his scientific knowledge and training, the
work of the Commission could notscarcely have been carried to a conclusion. Cir-
cumstances obliged Dr. Reed to leave Carroll in charge of the preliminary
experiments while he himself returned to the United States on business
connected with them, and it was entirely through Carroll's exertions at this time that
they were brought to a satisfactory conclusion & the demonstration was completed by the time Reed was again
in Cuba. Again, in February 1901, when the fact that yellow fever is
transmitted by the stegomyia calopus was finally provedn and Reed went
home, Carroll remained behind for several weeks to determine one or
two minor added points necessary to the perfect completion of the experiments.
But His most valuable, as well as most independent service to the Yellow
Fever Commission was rendered in the following summer, when he returned

The first paper which he published independently, was on the “The Treatment

For some years Carroll services received no official recognition,
but during the last year of his life honors began to accrue to him, in which
he took an straightforward andmainly honorable & justifiable pleasure. He was promoted from
? the rank of Lieutaenant to that of Major and two universities the U. of N. & the U. of Md. conferred upon
him the honorary degree of L L. D. In the summer of 1897 the heart lesion,
which originated during the attack of yellow fever., asserted itself and his
health began to fail. He died at his home in Washington in Octoberon September .16th
1907.

that he had the elements of success with in him from the first. He was the typ-

an essential part of its closest ally, and is often, pardonably, mistaken
